title: Responsive Design with Bootstrap
author: Wibecka Oliver
description: Tired of media-queries? Writing long html code for a simple nav bar? With a little help from Bootstrap, the time it takes for creating responsive design can be significantly reduced. Developed by Mark Otto and Jacob Thornton while at Twitter, Bootstrap provides a free, open source framework which recognizes screen dimensions and makes it possible to integrate responsive design easier. Built into Bootstrap are specific breakpoints, which inform the browser what changes to make to its inner contents when a screen has a particular dimension. The Bootstrap Library contains many different elements which are useful for any webpage, and provides code snippets in their documentation which can be easily copied and integrated into individual projects. Bootstrap offers custom nav bars, buttons, modules and other interesting components, as well as icons, utilities and animations. Additionally, Bootstrap contains a standard styling which can clean up a simple project to look more aesthetically pleasing. Rather than linking an external style sheet, bootstrap’s styling options and functionalities can be accessed through its various classes. For example, when constructing a simple button Bootstrap uses the ‘btn’ class. To make changes to this ‘btn’  class, it's possible to work within the bootstrap library by adding built in classes to this class. Adding ‘btn-primary’ will change the button color blue, while adding ‘btn-secondary’ will make the button gray. The entire class name will then read ‘btn btn-primary’. To integrate Bootstrap into a project is also relatively simple. It can be done through installing Bootstrap via a packet manager, or by simply including the necessary Bootstrap links within the index.html file. All information about how to install and use Bootstrap can be found in their documentation. With all that Bootstrap offers it may seem intimidating to use, however once understood  it can be a powerful tool in a developers arsenal.

title: HTML - An Introduction
author: Wibecka Oliver
description: Hyper Text Markup Language, or HTML, is one of the fundamental building blocks for web development. Invented by Tim-Berners Lee in the early 90s, HTML is responsible for informing browsers how text, or information rather should appear on the page. Each web-based project will contain at least one main .html file (index.html) which will provide the foundation for that site’s page layout. Within an .html file, content is broken down through the use of tags, which are written with opening and closing angle brackets like so: <html></html>. The example given is what wraps the entire content of a .html file. Within this content, the .html file can be divided into two primary sections, the head and the body. Within the head, meta information, or information about the document itself rather than information regarding the webpage’s content is placed. Beneath, in the body section desired page content can be distributed and organized through various tags. Each tag provides the browser with an instruction for how to display information on the webpage. For example, an 'h1' tag refers to a header, this means that the browser will display the enclosed text larger than, let's say, text within the 'p' tag, which simply refers to paragraph text.Another useful tag within html is the div tag, which allows for dividing chunks of content into containers which can then be organized and styled with the help of CSS or style tags. Attributes can also be placed within these tags to allow for easy customization and identification when integrating other code or files. The most basic attribute would be a class tag, which identifies that specific tag.Other tags, such as the image tag, require certain attributes to get the information that they need, such as source file and ask for an alternate text to assist screen readers and accessibility. Understanding how to format HTML tags is essential to creating functional and easy to understand web pages. This introductory guide is designed to provide a base understanding that will assist with the foundation of any web project, from small to large.

title: CSS - An Introduction
author: Wibecka Oliver
description: Cascading Style Sheets or CSS are used to alter default styling to present custom styling for different web-based projects. That is, CSS works directly in conjunction with HTML. Declaring different rules in a CSS file or within a style tag of an html file defines how a particular element will be displayed to the user. Styling works by declaring an id associated with an html element, and then providing a number of instructions, or rules for that element. An element can be declared by its tag, its class name or its id, depending on the syntax within the html file. After an element has been declared, within a set of braces, certain visual rules can be placed which will be relevant to all items belonging to that particular type of identification.  For example, if the ‘h1’ tag is selected, within a CSS stylesheet, it can be given that all text written within an h1 tag must be blue by assigning the ‘color’ rule or property to ‘blue’. Making a rule to cover all like-minded elements, or even to group specific elements within a certain styling format not only creates cohesive web pages, but minimizes repetitive code. Rather than making an explicit rule for each individual item, like-items can simply be grouped and then given the relevant styling properties. These properties can become very detailed, more so than assigning a color or font of a particular text. A stylesheet can also determine how spacing and layout works for that element. Maintaining padding, margins, and alignments are all possible within the stylesheet.  CSS also allows for certain imports for even further customization possibilities, such as from google fonts. Sass, a preprocessor to CSS developed around the mid 2000s is a kind of styling language which can then be compiled into CSS. With practiced use of CSS, any developer can master the art of creating a beautiful web page.
